item.title: Huge Crowds Turn Out for Hong Kong Pro-Democracy March
item.description: A huge throng of people, mostly young, took to Hong Kong’s streets Tuesday, defying Beijing’s dwindling tolerance for challenges to its control.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Protesters participated in one of the largest marches in Hong Kong's history on Tuesday.

item.title: Erdogan, Survivor of Protests and Inquiries, to Seek Turkey’s Presidency
item.description: The post, until now largely ceremonial, could become much more important under Mr. Erdogan, who has held power in Turkey for a decade.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Israel’s Search for 3 Teenagers Ends in Grief
item.description: The discovery of the teenagers’ bodies in the West Bank prompted vows of retaliation by Israel, which blamed the Palestinian group Hamas for the killings.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Israelis gathered in Gush Etzion on Monday for a vigil near the area where the bodies of three Israeli teenagers were found under a pile of rocks in a field.

item.title: Pistorius Planned a Trip Abroad With Steenkamp, Agent Says
item.description: The South African track star’s agent and friend testified that the couple’s relationship was strong and that he did not intend to kill her.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Japan Moves to Permit Greater Use of Its Military
item.description: The Japanese prime minister announced that his government would reinterpret the antiwar Constitution to allow the armed forces to come to the aid of friendly nations.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Details Emerge in Deaths of Israeli Teenagers
item.description: The first clues that led to the grisly discovery of the bodies came only hours after their abduction in the West Bank was reported.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Sunnis and Kurds Walk Out of Iraq Parliament
item.description: The lawmakers were under pressure to name an inclusive government as insurgents mount a violent challenge north and west of Baghdad.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Iraq Must Not Come Apart
item.description: The only viable political future for the country is federation. But America’s first priority is to see ISIS crushed.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By LESLIE H. GELB

item.title: Heavy Clashes After Ukraine’s Leader Ends Cease-Fire
item.description: President Petro O. Poroshenko said he would resume full-scale efforts to quash the pro-Russian uprising in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: A resident surveyed damage from recent shelling in Slovyansk, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: French Ex-President Sarkozy Held for Questioning
item.description: Nicolas Sarkozy, the former leader, has been under scrutiny for possible financial irregularities in his 2007 campaign and for other alleged offenses.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:description: Nicolas Sarkozy, the former president of France, in Paris last week.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Reaches Out to Myanmar on Maritime Dispute
item.description: Myanmar is enjoying some new diplomatic clout, leading China to court the country as Beijing presses its territorial claims in the South China Sea.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ and WAI MOE
item.media:description: President Thein Sein of Myanmar visiting a photo exhibition in Beijing marking the 60th anniversary of the Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence.

item.title: World Cup 2014: African Soccer Overshadowed by Protests
item.description: The last remaining African teams in the World Cup, Algeria and Nigeria, were eliminated on Monday, ensuring that the continent would once again remember the 2014 event for off-the-field squabbles.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID WALDSTEIN
item.media:description: Nigeria lost to France, 2-0, on Monday in the Round of 16. The team was one of three from Africa to protest to their soccer federation over finances, refusing to practice before being paid in cash.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong Survey Finds Record Dissatisfaction With Beijing
item.description: As Hong Kong prepared for its annual pro-democracy march Tuesday, a survey of residents found more discontent than ever with the Chinese government’s policies toward the city, especially among the young.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: An unofficial referendum in June on making the selection of Hong Kong's top official more democratic drew nearly 800,000 votes and angered China's central government.

item.title: Ukrainian President Ends Cease-Fire With Rebels
item.description: President Petro O. Poroshenko ended a 10-day cease-fire, saying that rebels had not put down their weapons and had persisted in attacking government troops.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Residents of Slovyansk, in eastern Ukraine, trying to fix a window shattered during shelling.

item.title: Mexican Soldiers Wage Bloody Battle With Gang
item.description: At least 22 people were killed in the firefight — all of them assailants, the military said. One soldier was injured.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: DealBook: BNP Paribas Admits Guilt and Agrees to Pay $8.9 Billion Fine to U.S.
item.description: The giant French bank admitted to transferring billions of dollars on behalf of Sudan and other countries the United States has blacklisted.
item.dc:creator: By BEN PROTESS and JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG
item.media:description: The headquarters of BNP Paribas in Paris. The bank agreed to pay an $8.9 billion penalty.

item.title: World Briefing: Indonesia: Life Sentence for Ex-Justice
item.description: The former chief justice of the Constitutional Court was sentenced to life in prison for corruption, the heaviest sentence ever for graft in one of the most corrupt countries in the world.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Czech Republic: Former Aide Convicted
item.description: A former aide to former Prime Minister Petr Necas who later married him was found guilty of abuse of power on Monday in a scandal that exposed their affair and toppled the government a year ago.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Chilean Court Rules U.S. Had Role in Murders
item.description: The court found that in 1973 an American naval officer provided Chilean officials with information on two Americans, which led to their executions as part of a coup that ousted President Salvador Allende.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By PASCALE BONNEFOY

item.title: No Bombast (for Now) as Toronto Mayor Comes Back
item.description: Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto returned to his job after undergoing drug and alcohol treatment, saying, “My top priority will be rebuilding trust.”
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto returned to his job Monday after time in a rehabilitation program.

item.title: Middle East Memo: ISIS Threatens Al Qaeda as Flagship Movement of Extremists
item.description: The question is whether the new group, which now calls itself simply the Islamic State, will endure.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: On Monday, members of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria paraded through Raqqa, Syria, the group’s de facto capital, in a show of success and mystique.

item.title: A Long History of Rebellion in the Mountains of Pakistan
item.description: The Waziristan region of Pakistan’s northwest is known as a haven for militants, with a 150-year history of insurgent campaigns.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS SCHORZMAN and KIRAN NAZISH

item.title: Germany 2, Algeria 1: World Cup 2014: Germany Prevails Over Algeria Despite Early Scare
item.description: In the first half, it looked as though Algeria knew where the holes worth exploiting could be found, but Germany reorganized for the second half and grabbed control in extra time.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER CLAREY
item.media:description: André Schürrle, left, scored the first goal of the game for Germany in the 92nd minute against Algerian goalkeeper Raïs M’Bolhi, alongside defender Faouzi Ghoulam.

item.title: The Vienna Philharmonic Recalls World War I in Sarajevo
item.description: The Vienna Philharmonic chose its material carefully for a concert held in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, that remembered World War I.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:description: In Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, people watch a live broadcast of the Vienna Philharmonic across from City Hall.

item.title: For Iraq, Potential Leader With a Tarnished Past
item.description: Ahmad Chalabi, once championed by the Bush administration as a possible leader for Iraq and then pushed aside for faulty depictions of weapons of mass destruction, has re-emerged in talks among the country’s political parties as a contender for prime minister.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ahmad Chalabi, center, last month at a camp for displaced Iraqis in Khazer. He is being considered for prime minister.
